unit.doc: Irmin public API.Irmin is a library to design and use persistent stores with built-in snapshot, branching and reverting mechanisms. Irmin uses concepts similar to http://git-scm.com/Git but it exposes them as a high level library instead of a complex command-line frontend. It features a bidirectional Git backend, fully-compatible with the usual Git tools and workflows.Irmin is designed to use a large variety of backends. It is written in pure OCaml and does not depend on external C stubs; it is thus very portable and aims is to run everywhere, from Linux to Xen unikernels.Consult the Irminbasics and Irminexamples of use for a quick start.Release %%VERSION%% - %%MAINTAINER%%

value.doc: The version of the library.

module.doc: Serializable data with reversible human-readable representations.

value.doc: Display a value using its human readable representation.
Convert an human readable representation of a value into its abstract value.Invalid_argumentif the string does not represent anything meaningful.

type.doc: Type for implementation of S for values of type 'a.

module.doc: Tasks are used to keep track of the origin of reads and writes in the store. Every high-level operation is expected to have its own task, which is passed to every low-level calls.

value.doc: Create a new task.

Get the task date.The date is computed by the user user when calling the IrminTaskcreatecreate function. When available, Unix.gettimeofday () is a good value for such date. On more esoteric platforms, any monotonic counter is a fine value as well. On the Git backend, the date will be translated into the commit Date field.
Get the task owner.The owner identifies the entity (human, unikernel, process, thread, etc) performing an operation. For the Git backend, this will be directly translated into the Author field.

Get the task unique identifier.By default, it is freshly generated on each call to IrminTaskcreatecreate. That identifier is useful for debugging purposes, for instance to relate debug lines to the tasks which cause them, and might appear in one line of the commit message for the Git backend.

Get the messages associated to the task.Text messages can be added to a task either at creation time, using IrminTaskcreatecreate, or can be appended on already created tasks using the IrminTaskaddadd function. For the Git backend, this will be translated to the commit message.
Add a message to the task messages list. See IrminTaskmessagesmessages for more details.

module.doc: Merge provides functions to build custom 3-way merge operators for various user-defined contents.
Base functions on results.

value.doc: Monadic bind for results.

exception.doc: Exception which might be raised when merging.

value.doc: Convert `Conflict results to Conflict exceptions.

type.doc: Signature of a merge function. /----> t1 ----\ ----> old |--> result \----> t2 ----/

value.doc: Call the merge functions in sequence. Stop as soon as one is not returning a conflict.
The apply combinator is useful to untie recursive loops when building a complex merge function.
Use the merge function defined in another domain. The domain converting functions might be partial: in that case the convention is that they raise Not_found on undefined entries.
Same as IrminMergebijectbiject but with blocking domain converting functions.
The default string merge function. Do not anything clever, just compare the strings using the default merge function.
Lift a merge function to optional values of the same type. If all the provided values are inhabited, then call the provided merge function, otherwise use the same behavior as create.
Lift merge functions to pair of elements.
Lift merge functions to triple of elements.
List merge functions to sets.

type.doc: The type for counter values. It is expected that the only valid operations on counters are increment and decrement. The following merge functions ensure that the counter semantics is preserved: i.e. it ensures that the number of increments and decrements is preserved.

value.doc: The merge function for mergeable counters.

module.doc: Multi-sets.

signature.comment:
We consider that the only valid operations for maps and association lists are:
Adding a new bindings to the map.
Removing a binding from the map.
Replacing an existing binding with a different value.
Trying to add an already existing binding is a no-op.We thus assume that no operation on maps is modifying the key names. So the following merge functions ensures that (i) new bindings are preserved (ii) removed bindings stay removed and (iii) modified bindings are merged using the merge function of values.Note: We only consider sets of bindings, instead of multisets. Application developer should take care of concurrent adding and removal of similar bindings themselves, by using the appropriate IrminMergeMSetmulti-sets.

value.doc: Lift the merge functions to association lists.

module.doc: Lift the merge functions to maps.

value.doc: Lift to X.t maps.

module.doc: Useful merge operators.open Irmin.Merge.OP at the top of your file to use them.

value.doc: Return `Ok x.
Return `Conflict str.
Same as bind.

type.doc: The type for user-defined tasks. See IrminTaskTask.
The type for backend-specific configuration values.Every backend has different configuration options, which are kept abstract to the user.

unit.comment: An Irmin store is automatically built from a number of lower-level stores, implementing fewer operations, such as IrminAOappend-only and IrminRWread-write stores. These low-level stores are provided by various backends.

value.doc: create config task is a function returning fresh store handles, with the configuration config and fresh tasks computed using task. config is provided by the backend and task is the provided by the user. The operation might be blocking, depending on the backend.
task t is the task associated to the store handle t.
Read a value from the store.
Same as read but raise Not_found if the key does not exist.
Check if a key exists.
Write the contents of a value to the store. That's the responsibility of the append-only store to generate a consistent key.
iter t fn call the function fn on all t's keys.
update t k v replaces the contents of k by v in t. If k is not already defined in t, create a fresh binding.
remove t k remove the key k in t.
watch t k is the stream values associated to the key k. The stream return a new value every time the bindings is modified in t. It return None if the binding is removed.

signature.comment: Hierarchical read-write stores are read-write stores using IrminPathStpaths as keys. They are a very simplified abstraction of filesystems.

type.doc: The type for step values. A step is a path component.

value.doc: list t k list the sub-paths of the path k in t.
Same as IrminRWremoveRW.remove but removes all the sub-paths recursively.

signature.comment: Branch-consistent StoreThey are two kinds of branch consistent stores: the IrminBCpersistentpersistent and the IrminBCtemporarytemporary ones.IrminBCpersistentPersistent StoresThe persistent stores are associated to a branch name, or IrminBCtagtag. The tag value is updated every time the store is updated, so every handle connected or which will be connected to the same tag will see the changes.These stores can be created using the IrminBCof_tagof_tag functions.

type.doc: Type for branch names, or tags. Tags usually share a common global namespace and that's the user responsibility to avoid name-clashes.

value.doc: create t tag is a persistent store handle. Similar to create, but use the tag branch instead of the master one.
tag t is the tag associated to the store handle t. None means that the branch is not persistent.
Same as tag but raise Not_found if the store handle is not persistent.
The list of all the tags of the store.
Change the current tag name. Fail if a tag with the same name already exists. The head is unchanged.
update_tag t tag updates t's current branch with the contents of the branch named tag.
merge_tag t tag merges the contents of the branch named tag into t's current branch. The two branches are still independent.
Same as IrminBCmerge_tag but raise IrminMergeConflict in case of a conflict.
Switch the store contents the be same as the contents of the given branch name. The two branches are still independent.

signature.comment: IrminBCtemporaryTemporary StoresThe temporary stores do not use global branch names. Instead, the operations are relative to a given store revision: a IrminBCheadhead. Every operation updates the store as a normal persistent store, but the value of head is only kept into the local store handle and it is not persisted into the store -- this means it cannot be easily shared by concurrent processes or loaded back in the future. In the Git terminology, these store handle are said to be detached heads.

value.doc: Create a temporary store handle, which will not persist as it has no associated to any persistent tag name.

Return the head commit. This works for both persistent and temporary stores. In the case of a persistent store, this involves looking into the value associated to the branch tag, so this might blocks. In the case of a temporary store, it is a simple (non-blocking) look-up in the store handle local state.
Same as read_head but raise Not_found if the commit does not exist.
branch t is the current branch of the store t. Can either be a persistent store with a tag name or a detached head.
The list of all the heads of the store.
Detach the current branch, i.e. it is not associated to a tag anymore.
Set the commit head.
Merge a commit with the current branch.
Same as IrminBCmerge_headmerge_head but raise IrminMergeConflict in case of a conflict.
Watch changes for a given collection of keys and the ones they have recursive access. Return the stream of heads corresponding to the modified keys.
Fork the store t, using the given branch name. Return None if a branch with the same name already exists.
Same as IrminBCcloneclone but delete and update the existing branch if a branch with the same name already exists.
merge x t i merges t x's current branch into i x's current branch. After that operation, the two stores are still independent.
Same as IrminBCmergemerge but raise IrminMergeConflict in case of a conflict.

export t ~depth ~min ~max exports the store slice between min and max, using at most depth history depth (starting from the max).If max is not specified, use the current heads. If min is not specified, use an unbound past (but can be still limited by depth).depth is used to limit the depth of the commit history. None here means no limitation.If full is set (default is true) the full graph, including the commits, nodes and contents, is exported, otherwise it is the commit history graph only.
import t s imports the contents of the slice s in t. Do not modify tags.

module.doc: Store paths.An Irmin IrminSstore binds IrminPathStpaths to user-defined IrminContentsScontents. Paths are composed by basic elements, that we call IrminPathSstepsteps. The following Path module provides functions to manipulate steps and paths.
A list of steps, representing keys in an Irmin store.
An implementation of paths as string lists.

Hashing functions.Hash provides user-defined hash function to digest serialized contents. Some Irminbackendbackends might be parameterize by such a hash functions, other might work with a fixed one (for instance, the Git format use only SHA1).An IrminHashSHA1SHA1 implementation is available to pass to the backends.

exception.doc: Exception raised when parsing a human-readable representation of a hash.

value.doc: Compute a deterministic store key from a cstruct value.
The kind of generated hash.
The raw hash value.
Abstract an hash value.

module.doc: SHA1 digests

Contents specifies how user-defined contents need to be serializable and mergeable.The user need to provide:
a to_sexp function for debugging purposes (that might expose the internal state of abstract values)
a pair of to_json and of_json functions, to be used by the REST interface.
a triple of size_of, write and read functions, to serialize data on disk or to send it over the network.
a 3-way merge function, to handle conflicts between multiple versions of the same contents.Default contents for IrminContentsStringstring, IrminContentsJsonJSON and IrminContentsCstructC-buffers like values are provided.

value.doc: Merge function. Evaluates to `Conflict if the values cannot be merged properly.

module.doc: String values where only the last modified value is kept on merge. If the value has been modified concurrently, the merge function raises Conflict.
JSON values where only the last modified value is kept on merge. If the value has been modified concurrently, the merge function raises Conflict.
Cstruct values where only the last modified value is kept on merge. If the value has been modified concurrently, then this is a conflict.

value.doc: merge t lifts the merge functions defined on contents values to contents key. The merge function will: (i) read the values associated with the given keys, (ii) use the merge function defined on values and (iii) write the resulting values into the store to get the resulting key.If any of these operation fails, return `Conflict.

module.doc: Key provides base functions for user-defined contents keys.
Val provides base function for user-defined contents values.
Make builds a contents store.
User-defined tags. Tags are used to specify branch names in an Irmin store.

module_type.doc: A tag implementations specifies base functions on abstract tags and define a default value for denoting the IrminTagSmastermaster branch name.

value.doc: The name of the master branch.

module.doc: String is an implementation of IrminTagSS where tags are strings. The master tag is "master".

module_type.doc: STORE specifies the signature of tag stores.A tag store is a key / value store, where keys are names created by users (and/or global names created by convention) and values are keys from the block store.A typical Irmin application should have a very low number of keys in the tag store.

module.doc: Base functions on keys.
Base functions on values.

unit.comment:
High-level StoresAn Irmin store is a branch-consistent store where keys are lists of steps.An example is a Git repository where keys are filenames, i.e. list of '\'-separated strings. More complex examples are structured values, where steps might contains first-class fields accessors and array offsets.Irmin provides the follow gin features:
Support for fast IrminBCclones, branches and merges, in a fashion very similar to Git.
Efficient IrminViewstaging areas for fast, transient, in-memory operations.
Space efficient IrminSnapshotsnapshots and fast and consistent rollback operations.
Fast IrminSyncsynchronization primitives between remote stores, using native backend protocols (as the Git protocol) when available.

module.doc: Private defines functions only useful for creating new backends. If you are just using the library (and not developing a new backend), you should not use this module.
Backend configuration.A backend configuration is a set of keyskeys mapping to typed values. Backends define their own keys.

signature.comment: Configuration convertersA configuration converter transforms a string value to an OCaml value and vice-versa. There are a few IrminPrivateConfbuiltin_convertersbuilt-in converters.

type.doc: The type for configuration converter parsers.
The type for configuration converter printers.

value.doc: parser c is c's parser.
converter c is c's printer.

type.doc: The type for configuration keys whose lookup value is 'a.

value.doc: key docs docv doc name conv default is a configuration key named name that maps to value v by default. converter is used to convert key values provided by end users.docs is the title of a documentation section under which the key is documented. doc is a short documentation string for the key, this should be a single sentence or paragraph starting with a capital letter and ending with a dot. docv is a meta-variable for representing the values of the key (e.g. "BOOL" for a boolean).Invalid_argumentif the key name is not made of a sequence of ASCII lowercase letter, digit, dash or underscore. FIXME not implemented.Warning. No two keys should share the same name as this may lead to difficulties in the UI.
The key name.
tc k is k's converter.
default k is k's default value.
doc k is k's documentation string (if any).
docv k is k's value documentation meta-variable (if any).
docs k is k's documentation section (if any).
Default --root=ROOT argument.
empty is the empty configuration.
singleton k v is the configuration where k maps to v.
is_empty c is true iff c is empty.
mem c k is true iff k has a mapping in c.
add c k v is c with k mapping to v.
rem c k is c with k unbound.
find c k is k's mapping in c, if any.
get c k is k's mapping in c.Raises. Not_found if k is not bound in d.
bool converts values with bool_of_string.
int converts values with int_of_string.
string converts values with the identity function.
uri converts values with Uri.of_string.
string converts values with the identity function.

module.doc: Watch provides helpers to register event notifications on read-write stores.

value.doc: Notify all listeners in the given watch state that a key has changed, with the new value associated to this key. If the argument is None, this means the key has been removed.
Create a watch state.
Clear all register listeners in the given watch state.
Create a stream of value notifications. Need to provide the initial value, or None if the key does not have associated contents yet.
Register a fsevents/inotify thread to look for changes in the given directory.
Register a function which looks for file changes in a directory. Could use inotify when available, or use an active stats file polling.
Lift a stream out of the monad.

module.doc: Make builds an implementation of watch helpers.

Node provides functions to describe the graph-like structured values.The node blocks form a labeled directed acyclic graph, labeled by IrminPathSstepsteps: a list of steps defines a unique path from one node to an other.Each node can point to user-defined IrminContentsScontents values.

type.doc: The type for steps between nodes.

value.doc: create l is a new node.
alist t is the contents of t.
The empty node.
Is the node empty?
Get the node contents.A node can point to user-defined IrminPrivateNodeScontentscontents. The edge between the node and that contents is labeled by a IrminPrivateNodeSstepstep.
iter_contents t f calls f on t's contents. For better performance, use IrminPrivateNodeScontentscontents instead when you know the step in advance.
with_contents t s c replaces t's contents for the step s by c.
succ t s is s's successor in t.
iter_succ t f calls f on t's successors.
replace_succ t s n replaces t's successor for the step s by n.

module.doc: Node provides a simple node implementation, parameterized by the contents C, node N and paths P.

module_type.doc: STORE specifies the signature for node stores.

module.doc: Step provides base functions on node steps.
Key provides base functions for node keys.
Val provides base functions for node values.

module_type.doc: Graph specifies the signature for node graphs. A node graph is a deterministic DAG, labeled by steps.

type.doc: The type of steps. A step is used to pass from one node to an other. A list of steps forms a path.

value.doc: The empty node.
Create a new node.
contents t n s is n's contents in t, associated to the step s.
succ t n s is n's successors in t, associated to the step s.
steps t n is the list of steps leaving the node t.
iter_contents f fn calls fn on t's contents.
iter_succ t fn calls fn on t's successors.
mem_contents t n path checks if there is a path labeled by path from n to a valid contents in t.
read_contents t n path is the contents at the end of the path starting from n and labeled by path in t. Return None if no such contents exists.
Same as IrminPrivateNodeGRAPHread_contents by raise Not_found if there is no valid contents.
add_contents t n path c adds the contents c as the end of the path starting from n and labeled by path in t.
remove_contents t n path removes the contents at the end of the path of the path starting from n and labeled by path in t.
mem_node t n checks if there is a path labeled by path from n to a valid node in t.
read_node t n path is the node at the end of the path starting from n and labeled by path in t. Return None if no such node exists.
Same as IrminPrivateNodeGRAPHread_noderead_node but raise Not_found if the path is invalid.
add_node t n path c adds the node c as the end of the path starting from n and labeled by path in t.
remove_node t n path removes the node at the end of the path of the path starting from n and labeled by path in t.
merge t is the 3-way merge function for nodes. FIXME: give semantics

closure t ~min ~max is the transitive closure c of t's nodes such that:
There is a path in t from any nodes in min to nodes in c. If min is empty, that condition is always true.
There is a path in t from any nodes in c to nodes in max. If max is empty, that condition is always false.Note: Both min and max are subsets of c.

module.doc: Graph nodes forms a IrminContentsSTOREcontents store.

Commit values represent the store history.Every commit contains a list of predecessor commits, and the collection of commits form an acyclic directed graph.Every commit also can contain an optional key, pointing to a IrminPrivateCommitSTOREnode value. See the IrminPrivateNodeSTORENode signature for more details on node values.The signature for slices.

value.doc: Create a commit.
The underlying node.
The commit parents.
The commit provenance.

module.doc: Make provides a simple implementation of commit values, parameterized by the commit C and node N.

module_type.doc: STORE specifies the signature for commit stores.

module.doc: Key provides base functions for commit keys.
Val provides function for commit values.

module_type.doc: History specifies the signature for commit history. The history is represented as a partial-order of commits and basic functions to search through that history are provided.Every commit can point to an entry point in a node graph, where user-defined contents are stored.

value.doc: Create a new commit.
Get the commit node.A commit might contain a graph IrminPrivateNodeGRAPHnodenode.
Get the commit parents.Commits form a append-only, fully functional, partial-order data-structure: every commit carries the list of its immediate predecessors.
merge t is the 3-way merge function for commit.
Find the least common ancestors http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lowest_common_ancestorlca between two commits.
Same as IrminPrivateNodeGRAPHclosureGRAPH.closure but for the history graph.

module.doc: An history forms a IrminContentsSTOREcontents store.
Build a commit history.

value.doc: Create a new empty slice.
add_contents t c adds the contents c to the slice t.
add_node t n adds the node n to the slice t.
add_commit t c adds the commit c to the slice t.
iter_contents t f calls f on t's contents.
iter_nodes t f calls f on t's nodes.
iter_commits t f calls f on t's commits.

module.doc: Build simple slices.

value.doc: Create a remote store handle.

fetch t uri fetches the contents of the remote store located at uri into the local store t. Return the head of the remote branch with the same name, which is now in the local store. None is no such branch exists.
push t uri pushes the contents of the local store t into the remote store located at uri.

module.doc: None is an implementation of IrminPrivateSyncSS which does nothing.

module_type.doc: The complete collection of private implementations.

module.doc: Private contents.
Private nodes.
Private commits.
Private tags.
Private slices.
Key provides base functions on step lists.
Val provides base functions on user-defined, mergeable contents.
Tag provides base functions on user-defined tags.
Head provides base functions on head values.
Private functions, which might be used by the backends.

module_type.doc: S_MAKER is the signature exposed by any backend providing IrminS implementations. S is the type of steps (a key is list of steps), C is the implementation of user-defined contents, T is the implementation of store tags and H is the implementation of store heads. It does not use any native synchronization primitives.

unit.comment:
The basic API considers default Irmin implementations using:
IrminPathString_listlist of strings as keys.
IrminTagStringstrings as tags.
IrminHashSHA1SHA1 as internal digests.Only the IrminContentsScontents is provided by the user.

module.doc: Generate a basic store using B as backend and C as user-provided contents.

value.doc: basic backend contents is a basic Irmin implementation using backend as a backend and containing values defined by contents.
See IrminROcreate. Needs a backend as first argument.
See IrminBCof_tag. Needs a backend as first argument.
See IrminBCof_head. Needs a backend as first argument.
See IrminROread.
See IrminROread_exn.
See IrminROmem.
See IrminRWiter.
See IrminRWupdate.
See IrminRWremove.
See IrminRWwatch.
See IrminHRWlist.
See IrminHRWremove_rec.
See IrminBCtag.
See IrminBCtag_exn.
See IrminBCtags.
See IrminBCrename_tag.
See IrminBCupdate_tag.
See IrminBCmerge_tag.
See IrminBCmerge_tag_exn.
See IrminBCswitch.
See IrminBChead.
See IrminBChead_exn.
See IrminBCbranch.
See IrminBCheads.
See IrminBCdetach.
See IrminBCupdate_head.
See IrminBCmerge_head.
See IrminBCmerge_head_exn.
See IrminBCwatch_head.
See IrminBCclone.
See IrminBCclone_force.
See IrminBCmerge.
See IrminBCmerge_exn.

unit.comment:
IrminexamplesExamplesThese examples are in the examples directory of the distribution.Mergeable logsWe want to define mergeable debug log. We first define a log entry as a pair of a timestamp and a message, using the combinator exposed by https://github.com/mirage/mirage-tcmirage-tc: module Entry = struct include Tc.Pair (Tc.Int)(Tc.String) let compare (x, _) (y, _) = Pervasives.compare x y let time = ref 0 let create message = incr time; !time, message endA log file is a list of entries (one per line), ordered by decreasing order of timestamps. The 3-way merge operator for log files concatenates and sorts the new entries and prepend them to the common ancestor's ones. module Log: Irmin.Contents.S with type t = Entry.t list = struct include Tc.List(Entry)
(* Get the timestamp of the latest entry. *) let timestamp = function | [] -> 0 | (timestamp, _ ) :: _ -> timestamp
(* Compute the entries newer than the given timestamp. *) let newer_than timestamp entries = let rec aux acc = function | [] -> List.rev acc | (h, _) :: _ when h <= timestamp -> List.rev acc | h::t -> aux (h::acc) t in aux [] entries
let merge ~old t1 t2 = let open Irmin.Merge.OP in let ts = timestamp old in let t1 = newer_than ts t1 in let t2 = newer_than ts t2 in let t3 = List.sort Entry.compare (List.rev_append t1 t2) in ok (List.rev_append t3 old) endNote: The serialization primitives provided by https://github.com/mirage/mirage-tcmirage-tc: are not very efficient in this case as they parse the file every-time. For real usage, you would write buffered versions of Log.read and Log.write.To persist the log file on disk, we need to choose a backend. We show here how to use the on-disk Git backend on Unix. (* Bring [Git_unix.task] and [Git_unix.Irmin_git] in scope. *) open Irmin_unix
(* Build an Irmin store containing log files. *) let store = Irmin.basic (module Irmin_git.FS) (module Log)
(* Set-up the local configuration of the Git repository. *) let config = Irmin_git.config ~root:"/tmp/irmin/test" ~bare:true ()We can now define a toy example to use our mergeable log files. (* Name of the log file. *) let file = [ "local"; "debug" ]
(* Read the entire log file. *) let read_file t = Irmin.read (t "Reading the log file") file >>= function | None -> return_nil | Some l -> return l
(* Persist a new entry in the log. *) let log t fmt = Printf.ksprintf (fun message -> read_file t >>= fun logs -> let logs = Entry.create message :: logs in Irmin.update (t "Adding a new entry") file logs ) fmt
let () = Lwt_unix.run begin Irmin.create store config task >>= fun t -> log t "Adding a new log entry" >>= fun () -> Irmin.clone_force task (t "Cloning the store") "x" >>= fun x -> log x "Adding new stuff to x" >>= fun () -> log x "Adding more stuff to x" >>= fun () -> log x "More. Stuff. To x." >>= fun () -> log t "I can add stuff on t also" >>= fun () -> log t "Yes. On t!" >>= fun () -> Irmin.merge_exn "Merging x into t" x ~into:t >>= fun () -> return_unit end

value.doc: remote_uri s is the remote store located at uri. Use the optimized native synchronization protocol when available for the given backend.

remote_store t is the remote corresponding to the local store t. Synchronization is done by importing and exporting store IrminBCsliceslices, so this is usually much slower than native synchronization using Irminremote_uri but it works for all backends.

module.doc: Sync provides functions to synchronization an Irmin store with local and remote Irmin stores.

value.doc: fetch t ?depth r populate the local store t with objects for the remote store r, using t's current branch. The depth parameter limits the history depth. Return None if either the local or remote store do not have a valid head.
Same as IrminSyncfetch but raise Failure if either the local or remote store do not have a valid head.

pull t ?depth r s is similar to IrminSyncfetchfetch but it also updates t's current branch. s is the update strategy:
`Merge uses .merge_head. This strategy can return a conflict.
`Update uses .update_head.
Same as IrminSyncpull but raise IrminMergeConflict in case of conflict.

push t ?depth r populates the remote store r with objects from the current store t, using t's current branch. If b is t's current branch, push also updates the head of b in r to be the same as in t.Note: Git semantics is to update b only if the new head if more recent. This is not the case in Irmin.
Same as IrminSyncpush but raise Failure if an error happen.

module.doc: View provides an in-memory partial mirror of the store, with lazy reads and delayed write.Views are like staging area in Git: they are temporary non-persistent areas (they disappear if the host crash), hold in memory for efficiency, where reads are done lazily and writes are done only when needed on commit: if if you modify a key twice, only the last change will be written to the store when you commit. Views also hold a list of operations, which are checked for conflicts on commits and are used to replay/rebase the view if needed. The most important feature of views is that they keep track of reads: i.e. you can have a conflict if a view reads a key which has been modified concurrently by someone else.

value.doc: Create an empty view. Empty views do not have associated backend configuration values, as they can perform in-memory operation, independently of any given backend.
rebase x t i rebases the actions done on the view t x into the view i x. If a read operation doesn't return the same result, return Conflict. Only the view i is updated.
Same as IrminViewrebase but raise IrminMergeConflict in case of conflict.
Read a view from a path in the store. This is a cheap operation, all the real reads operation will be done on-demand when the view is used.
update_path x t path v replaces the sub-tree under path in the store t x by the contents of the view v x. See IrminViewmerge_path for more details.

rebase_path x t path v rebases the view v x on top of the contents of t x's sub-tree pointed by the path path. Rebasing means re-applying every IrminViewActiontactions stored in t, including the reads. Return IrminMergeConflict if one of the action cannot apply cleanly. See IrminViewmerge_path for more details.
Same as IrminViewrebase_path but raise IrminMergeConflict in case of conflict.

merge_path x t path v merges the view v x with the contents of t x's sub-tree pointed by the path path. Merging means applying the IrminMergeMapmerge function for map between the view's contents and t's sub-tree.
IrminViewupdate_path discards any preexisting sub-tree.
IrminViewrebase_path is operation based. It keeps track of read operations which can lead to IrminMergeConflictconflicts. It replays the full operation history of the view on top of any preexisting sub-tree.
IrminViewmerge_path is state based. Is is an efficient 3-way merge operators between prefix trees, based on IrminMergeMapmerge.
Same as IrminViewmerge_path but raise IrminMergeConflict in case of conflicts.

module.doc: Action provides information about operations performed on a view.Each view stores the list of IrminViewActiontactions that have already been performed on it. These actions are useful when the view needs to be rebased: write operations are replayed while read results are checked against the original run.Signature for actions performed on a view.

type.doc: Operations on view. The read results are kept to be able to replay them on merge and to check for possible conflict: this happens if the result read is different from the one recorded.

value.doc: Pretty-print an action.
Pretty-print a sequence of actions.
Return the list of actions performed on this view since its creation.

module.doc: Snapshot provides read-only, space-efficient, checkpoints of a store. It also provides functions to rollback to a previous state.

value.doc: Pretty-print a snapshot value.
Read a pretty-printed snapshot value.
Snapshot the current state of the store.
Revert the store to a previous state.
Merge the given snapshot into the current branch of the store.
Same as IrminSnapshotmerge but raise IrminMergeConflict in case of conflict.
Subscribe to the stream of modification events attached to a given path. Takes and returns a new snapshot every time a sub-path is modified.

module.doc: Dot provides functions to export a store to the Graphviz `dot` format.

value.doc: output_buffer t ?html ?depth ?full buf outputs the Graphviz representation of t in the buffer buf.html (default is false) enables HTML labels.depth is used to limit the depth of the commit history. None here means no limitation.If full is set (default is not) the full graph, including the commits, nodes and contents, is exported, otherwise it is the commit history graph only.

unit.comment:
API to create new Irmin backends. A backend is an implementation exposing either a concrete implementation of IrminS or a functor providing IrminS once applied.There are two ways to create a concrete IrminS implementation:
IrminMake creates a store where all the objects are stored in the same store, using the same internal keys format and a custom binary format based on https://github.com/janestreet/bin_protbin_prot, with no native synchronization primitives: it is usually what is needed to quickly create a new backend.
IrminMake_ext creates a store with a deep embedding of each of the internal stores into separate store, with a total control over the binary format and using the native synchronization protocols when available. This is mainly used by the Git backend, but could be used for other similar backends as well in the future.

module_type.doc: AO_MAKER is the signature exposed by any backend providing append-only stores. K is the implementation of keys and V is the implementation of values.
RW_MAKER is the signature exposed by any backend providing read-write stores. K is the implementation of keys and V is the implementation of values.

module.doc: Simple store creator. Use the same type of all of the internal keys and store all the values in the same store.
Advanced store creator.
